message:
Guys, I'm starting a hobby project in C++ that will runs in *nix environment. It's merely calling a set of standard REST web services in a large scale, so I'm looking for the most lightweight, performant, and uncluttered way of doing it. My current options are:

1. Visual Studio as an IDE (productive), KDevelop and CMake to generate linux native executable (the most appealing option until now)

2.  C++.NET and Mono. It unlock the power of .NET, yet still concerned about performance and Mono support on the long run 

What you think?

data.message: I think if you have access to SublimeText it is my favorite, you can always configure it to build using whatever command line utility you want.

I didn't work with .Net frameworks before. So I'll vote with KDevelop and CMake combo. 
Because CMake is a cross platform build system. You can generate build files for VIsual Studio(Windows), XCode (Mac OS), Makefile (Unix) and finally Eclipse CDT projects (and other build systems I never used). 
So if you want your project to be cross platform then go for KDevelop and CMake combo.

- I am using CMake, makes my build environment easier.
- I use geany (text editor), sometimes vim. I have developed two different distributed tasks schedulers using python and C++ with them :D and it was a very good experience :D
- I always write scripts that install all my application dependencies ..
- Besides the dev. environment, you will need a good client (lightweight with good performance), what are your current options?
